topic.title: [PSA] Help distribute files on ZeroNet!
topic.body: A lot of websites that rely on storage (NullPaste, ZeroMaps etc.) have the option to distribute files! They're only a couple dozen megabytes for each site and unlike Tor, you don't need to have fancy equipment to speed up ZeroNet for everyone, so turn that option on!

topic.title: [PSA] Update your ZeroNet client periodically!
topic.body:
A quick look at the [stats](127.0.0.1:43110/Stats) page for ZeroNet reveals that a lot of people are running versions lower than 0.5.4 rev 2080, which is the latest as of now. Some clients seem to be running versions as old as 0.3.7, which was released last year (according to GitHub).
###Updating takes less than 30 seconds. Here's how to do it.
1. On the main page (ZeroHello), click the three dots menu on the top left, and select the second to last option "Version xxxx".
2. Click "Update"
3. Wait for ZeroNet to reload.

It's important that you _update at least once a month_ to keep your ZeroNet client running smoothly, and to install important security fixes.

topic.title: Tiddlywiki - a non-linear personal web notebook
topic.body:
Hi everyone, I wanted to share something I found on the clearnet and bring it to ZeroNet.

It's called Tiddlywiki, and it's a notebook that you can edit _anywhere_, with any browser, even without an internet connection!

The whole notebook is stored as a single HTML file with all the Javascript included, and you can export your own copy at any time, including options to enable encryption. Since it doesn't rely on any server-side logic, it makes a great method of creating ZeroNet sites, one can imagine creating a blog or a wiki with Tiddlywiki.

I created a demo site cloned from tiddlywiki.com, please check it out and you can indeed verify in your data folder that it only uses index.html and nothing else.

53_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv.body: ZeroNet sites are sandboxed for security, and keep in mind since you're running code in the browser the biggest security risk is if someone made a Javascript or other browser exploit that allowed them to gain elevated privileges or execute arbitrary code, which should be unlikely.

> [kai0](#comment_119_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): do you mean it can work outside of the sandbox by browser? or just run arbitrary code inside the sandbox?

Oh yeah I meant code execution _outside_ the sandbox. Within the sandbox would be things like animations, read/write files etc.
